5. Tuning MIEC/TCO as SIMs in SIMFCs

Synthesis of SIMFC materials involves complicated processes that require dedicated customization of composition, structure, and morphology control. We will explore standard experimental methods such as solid-state synthesis, sol-gel techniques, chemical vapor deposition, and physical vapor deposition. By understanding these methods, researchers can effectively tune MIECs to be tailored for the properties of SIMs and SIMFCs and optimize their properties/performances, to be described in this section. Tuning MIECs/TCOs as SIMs is a crucial aspect of SIMFC research and development. This includes controlling the ionic and electronic conductivities and the overall stability and compatibility of the MIEC materials within the fuel cell environment. Dopants and compositional engineering techniques have introduced defects or vacancies within the single-phase crystal structure or two-phase, typically, a semiconductor and an ionic phase heterostructure composites. These modifications create pathways for H + /O 2− ionic and e − /h + electronic conductions, enabling the materials from MIEC/TCO behavior towards more functional SIMs.
By carefully selecting suitable dopants or adjusting the stoichiometry of the oxides, e.g., perovskite, fluorite, or other structures, it is possible to engineer a balance between proton, oxygen ion, and electron conduction. Oxygen vacancies in the rare earth and transition metal dopants can introduce electrons as a hole's carrier within the crystal lattice, facilitating the movement of all concerned charges. The simultaneous transport of H + /O 2− and e − /h + charge carriers can promote kinetics in electrode redox reactions and also transport across the membrane that promotes efficient electrochemical reactions at the electrode-electrolyte interfaces, leading to an enhanced cell performance. A SIMFC device is mostly constructed by using Ni foam-pasted NCAL (a triple conducting semiconductor, Ni 0.8 Co 0.15 Al 0.05 LiO 2 ) [ 172 ] for symmetrical electrodes attached to SIM membranes in the configuration of Ni-NCAL/SIM/NCAL-Ni. The standard co-precipitation and solid-state reaction methods were commonly employed to synthesize the SIM material. This can be achieved by using either single-phase materials with precise particle sizes and uniform chemical/microstructure or two-phase materials with well-connected interfaces, creating a heterostructure with specific characteristics [ [173] , [174] , [175] , [176] ].
In a SIMFC, a new methodology has been developed to enhance the conduction of protons. The main objective is to optimize proton transport along the grain boundaries and interfaces of the electrolyte material to improve the overall cell performance. The original electrolyte LSCF/SCDC is known as MIEC. In this context, it allows the movement of both oxygen ions and electrons which increase the conduction of protons. The oxygen ions (O 2− ) generated at the cathode migrate through the lattice structure of LSCF/SCDC toward the anode. This movement is facilitated by the mixed ionic/electronic conduction of LSCF/SCDC.
This new approach promotes efficient proton transport along the grain boundaries of SCDC, as it is the most effective pathway known to us for proton conductivity. To implement this approach, NCAL (Ni 0.8 Co 0.15 Al 0.05 LiO 2 ) was to form symmetric electrodes that are sandwiched with an SCDC electrolyte in between them for this specific fuel cell configuration ( Fig. 7 a). shows the SCDC electrolyte in a cell that does not require a dedicated sintering process. In this state, the SCDC particles are interconnected, forming a network similar to a spider's web at the grain boundaries. This unique structure allows efficient proton transport beyond the crystal lattice, exploiting the grain boundary as the primary pathway for proton conductivity. For a side-by-side comparison, there is a sintered SCDC layer ( Fig. 7 b), in which the spider-like grain boundary structure is no longer found, they are transformed during the GDC particles densifying process and only show low proton conductivity along the structural bulk conduction pathways.
A novel material is developed by coating SCDC onto another electrolyte material, LSCF. Fig. 7 c illustrates the schematic synthesis process for SCDC/LSCF. Subsequently, the original SCDC electrolyte layer in the fuel cell is replaced with SCDC/LSCF, resulting in an MIEC, Ni-NCAL/(LSCF/SCDC)/NCAL-Ni configuration ( Fig. 7 d). This modification introduces LSCF doping into the SCDC electrolyte, enhancing both ionic and electronic conductivity. This integration creates additional pathways for proton conduction, and the incorporation of LSCF generates a built-in electric field (BIEF) at the interfaces, further promoting proton transport within the fuel cell. These enhancements collectively elevate proton conductivity, rendering the fuel cell highly suitable for efficient operation [ [177] , [178] , [179] , [180] , [181] , [182] ].
Recent efforts for developing SIMs focus on modifying the structure and surface interfaces, utilizing perovskite, spinel, fluorite, or other oxide structures. Doping alters interface properties and enhances ionic conductivity through specific surface interfaces. However, creating superior ionic conduction and achieving a complete understanding of interfacial analysis remain challenges as the phenomena discovered were still new to the solid state ionics society: the material's defect study and their engineering potentially lead a role in designing high ionic conductive materials by creating and customizing vacancies and enhancing mobility. Other widely used methodologies are improving the ionic conductivity by constructing MIECs and ionic conductors, e.g., LSCF/SCDC, to form composite systems to develop functional SIMs, where modulating interfaces, such as grain boundaries or heterointerfaces, is possible to create additional ionic conduction pathways whilst reducing electronic short circuits. This can be achieved through the dedicated engineering of the microstructures and composition gradients with the MIEC materials. Hence, research efforts should focus on fabricating nanostructured membranes using cost-effective nanotechnology. Additionally, studying new approaches like nano-redox devices and developing theoretical models, such as the space charge model, can aid in understanding SIMFCs and designing novel materials [ [183] , [184] , [185] , [186] ]. Optimizing the characteristics of MIECs as SIMs is vital for SIMFC advancement, which requires precise control of ionic and electronic conductivity, stability, and compatibility within the fuel cell operational environment. Due to scientific challenges associated with controlling them towards achieving the ultimate performance of SIMFCs, further experimental demonstration is deserved.

6. SIMFC junction devices with MIEC-tuned SIMs

SIMFCs present an innovative approach adopted in advanced fuel cell technology by replacing the traditional electrolyte with a more functional SIM membrane tuned by MIEC. The concept raises a crucial question: how does a membrane with MIEC avoid the electronic short-circuiting problem across itself within the device when applying the conventional understanding of having an electrolyte layer which must be an electronic insulator within SOFCs/PCFCs in order to prevent the electronic short-circuiting problem as well as electrochemical leakages. Some valid explanations exist by understanding the junction mechanisms that are formed in-situ during the operation of the SIMFC. Such mechanisms are taking the crucial role in understanding, and hence improving, the charge transfer and overall electrochemical performance of the SIMFC. In this regard, we will explore different junction mechanisms involved in SIMFC operation, including the SIM membrane and interfaces between the SIM and electrodes. In SIMFCs, Schottky junction and built-in electric field (BIEF) spontaneously occur, and enable the SIMFC membrane to achieve efficient ion transfer and charge separation that complete the electrochemical reactions whilst suppressing an electronic short-circuiting.
Various junctions have been reported that can solve the electronic short circuit problem due to using SIMs as fuel cell membranes with enhanced ionic conductivity and fuel cell performances. The bulk p-n heterojunction was first reported to interpret the single-layer fuel cell using homogenously mixed electron and ion-conducting materials [ 116 , 187 ]. In addition, the Schottky junction effect was employed later on to effectively explain how a single-layer fuel cell (a monolithic component) device prevented electrons’ crossover between the electrode and semiconductor membrane to suppress an electron short-circuit problem ( Fig. 8 a) [ 188 ]. A Schottky junction is formed at the interface between a converted metallic electrode (reduced to a metallic electrode during the anode reduction process) and the semiconductor material. In SIMFCs, this junction enables the selective orientation of charge carriers and facilitates the efficient transfer of ions across the interface whilst blocking the flow of electrons across the Schottky junction. The Schottky junction acts as a barrier for the crossing-over of electrons, only allowing charge carriers that possess a sufficient amount of excitation energy to overcome the obstacle barrier in order to participate in the electrochemical reactions. This selective orientation controls the flow of the charge carriers and the flow of the electrons helping to prevent an electronic short-circuit problem whilst ensuring the flow of electrons follows the desired direction.
The hybrid junction based on bulk p-n heterojunction and Schottky junction may commonly exist in the SIMFC device [ 189 , 190 ]. Xing et al. [ 155 ] demonstrated the construction of a semiconductor-based fuel cell (SBFC) using a core-shell structure of the same semiconductor material, specifically in CeO 2 /CeO 2-δ . Modifying the surface CeO 2 through a heat treatment process followed by reduction processes to enhance the oxygen-deficient CeO 2-δ layer's electrical properties. The amorphous CeO 2 core-shell acts as an insulator, while the oxygen-deficient CeO 2-δ surface layer is an excellent electronic conductor. This results in forming a BIEF directed from the core to the surface between the intrinsic semiconductor CeO 2 and the n-type semiconductor CeO 2-δ . The BIEF repels H + ions, allowing them to be transported only in the channels between the core-shell CeO 2 /CeO 2-δ particles, rather than having them migrate from the shell/surface to the bulk.
As explained above, within SIMFCs, the BIEF is formed spontaneously, and that can be strategically engineered to guide and direct the movement of charge carriers to satisfy the FC operator's demands: transporting electrons, and ions, to their desired destinations throughout the correct directions. The BIEF in SIMFCs aids in separating electron and ion transport pathways, ensuring that electrons predominantly flow through the metal electrode while ions migrate through the SIM membrane [ 191 ]. This separation of charge carriers is crucial for preventing electronic short circuits and maintaining the electrochemical integrity of the fuel cell. By carefully designing the energy band alignment and engineering the BIEF at the Schottky junction and throughout the MIEC membrane, SIMFCs can effectively control the movement of electrons and ions, facilitating efficient charge transfer and preventing electronic short-circuiting. This control of charge carrier transport pathways contributes to the overall performance and stability of SIMFCs [ 130 , 192 ].
Energy band alignment is critical in avoiding electronic short circuits and important for enhanced ionic transport due to the BIEF effect [ 191 ] common band alignment, e.g., type I and type II ( Fig. 8 b). In type-I heterostructure, electrons, and holes experience a potential barrier, while in the type-II heterostructure, electrons or holes encounter the wall [ 193 ]. Type-I heterostructure has a lower band gap in semiconductor (1) compared to semiconductor (2), resulting in charge carrier accumulation in semiconductor (2) and decreased electron mobility and activity. In type-II heterostructure, the flow of electrons and holes occurs in opposite directions, suppressing electronic conduction. Both types are suitable for energy conversion and storage devices by preventing short circuits. Type-II heterostructure with large exciton binding energy and tunable band gap is particularly advantageous, and they were used as a membrane in advanced ceramic fuel cells [ 194 , 195 ]. Furthermore, a p-n-n-p heterojunction is a semiconductor junction consisting of two p-n junctions with an additional layer in between. The p-n-n-p structure is formed by sandwiching an n-type semiconductor layer between two p-type semiconductor layers. This configuration creates two p-n junctions, one on each side of the n-type layer.
The essential characteristic of a p-n-n-p heterojunction is the difference in band gap energies between the materials used for the p-type and n-type regions. This band gap discontinuity leads to unique electronic properties and can be advantageous for SIMFC applications. The n-type layer in the middle introduces additional possibilities for device design and functionality. It can provide a region with different electronic properties or act as a barrier, influencing the flow of charge carriers and the overall behavior of the device ( Fig. 8 d). Shah et al. [ 38 ] proposed a type II semiconductor heterostructure consisting of Mg-doped ZnO, and pure ZnO. This heterostructure effectively blocks electron flow while promoting enhanced ionic transport, resulting in a significant fuel cell performance of 673 ​mW ​cm −2 . Furthermore, the Mg-doped ZnO/ZnO heterostructure demonstrated even higher performance, delivering 997 ​mW ​cm −2 with an open-circuit voltage (OCV) of 1.04 ​V at a temperature of 520 ​°C [ 116 , 147 , 196 ].
Promising advances have emerged in developing high ionic conducting electrolytes for LT-SOFCs through p-n heterostructure strategies. This study proposes a p-n-n structure approach utilizing p-type Ni 0.8 Co 0.15 Al 0.05 LiO 2−δ (NCAL), n-type ZnO, and n-type SnO 2 to create new LT-SOFC electrolytes [ 197 ]. Material characterization reveals a desirable heterostructure in the NCAL-ZnO-SnO 2 electrolyte, exhibiting homogeneous distribution, enriched oxygen vacancies, and well-defined hetero-interfaces. The electrochemical analysis demonstrates that the electrical conductivity and fuel cell performance strongly depend on the mass ratios of the p/n phases. The 2NCAL-1(ZnO-SnO 2 ) composition displays exceptional characteristics, including the highest ionic conductivity of 0.389 ​S/cm ​at 530 ​°C and an impressive fuel cell power density of 1267 ​mW ​cm −2 , surpassing the performance of NCAL-ZnO and NCAL-SnO 2 p-n heterostructure electrolytes. Overall, p-n-n-p heterojunction offers versatility in device design and provides an avenue for optimizing the performance of semiconductor devices through careful control of material properties and band gap engineering [ 164 ].
Semiconductor heterostructure composites are considered advanced electrolytes for LT-SOFCs. These heterostructures demonstrate significant enhancements in cell properties by utilizing different semiconductors with suitable energy band matching and interface effects, along with their BIEF. One interesting approach is to combine p-type and n-type semiconductors to form a gap-n junction, enabling efficient charge separation and accelerated ion transport along the heterojunction or semiconductor interface. This p-n heterojunction composite material can be utilized as an electronic leakage-free electrolyte ( Fig. 8 c) [ 150 , [198] , [199] , [200] , [201] ]. Several factors influence the performance of SIMFCs. This includes the effects of temperature on SIMs, electrode materials, SIM thickness, and the electrochemical reactions occurring at the SIM-electrode interfaces. By analyzing these factors, we can gain insights into the optimization of SIMFC performance and identify strategies to enhance the overall efficiency and stability of SIMFC devices. By examining experimental methods, tuning strategies, junction mechanisms, and performance-affecting factors, this chapter aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the application of SIMFCs and the critical considerations in designing and optimizing these advanced fuel cell systems.

6.1. DFT on surficial and interfacial disordering & heterojunction SIMs

Recent advancements in computational techniques have revolutionized materials research and engineering. In the field of tackling energy and environmental concerns, numerous electrochemical devices, including fuel cells, have arisen, with PCFC/SIMFC standing out due to their efficiency and solid-state construction. Investigating cathodes is critical for improving cell performance in the area of Proton-conducting solid oxide fuel cells (H-SOFC). Microstructure optimization and novel materials are acknowledged strategies for extending the reaction area. While refining microstructures with nanoscale cathodes increases cathode-electrolyte bonding, particle size and high-temperature coarsening susceptibility are the real constraints. H-SOFC cathodes differ from oxygen-ion conducting (O-SOFC) electrolytes in that they allow proton migration, oxygen-ion mobility, and electron conduction. Integrated proton conduction increases performance potential, and triple-conducting cathodes (proton, oxygen-ion and electron) are gaining much more attention. Nonetheless, because of strong electronic conductivity and limitations of standard approaches such as electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, estimating proton conduction in cathode materials is more difficult than in proton-conductive electrolytes ( Fig. 9 a).

6.1.1. Prediction of material property

Initially investigated, the use of density functional theory (DFT) in recent years has produced substantial insights into the atomic-level characteristics of PCFC/SIMFC and assisted the design of proton-conducting oxide materials. DFT's function in forecasting cathode material behavior is particularly significant, providing a method to improve cathode performance in PCFC. Density functional theory (DFT) simulations have emerged as powerful tools for understanding the electronic and ionic properties of materials at the atomic level. In the context of MIECs and SIMs, DFT provides valuable insights into the surficial and interfacial properties and heterojunction formation, which are crucial for enabling fast ionic conduction [ 202 ]. The DFT simulations enable researchers to predict the properties of new SIM materials and guide their rational design. Researchers can identify materials with desirable ionic conductivity, electronic bandgap, and stability by exploring different compositions, dopants, defects, and crystal structures. This predictive capability will accelerate the discovery of tailored SIM materials with optimized performance for various energy conversion and storage applications.

6.1.2. Interface engineering

Interface engineering plays a critical role in improving the performance of SIMFCs. DFT simulations offer a detailed understanding of the interfacial interactions and charge transport at interfaces between different SIM layers which has been emphasized in recent publications [ 178 , 203 , 204 ]. By modelling the interfacial phenomena, researchers can tailor the heterojunctions and optimize the interfaces to enhance ionic conduction and suppress electronic leakage. This knowledge will lead to the design of more efficient SIMFCs with improved performance and durability. Yousaf et al. [ 200 ] presents an innovative approach to enhance proton conduction in MIECs. This study explores the influence of interfacial disorder and heterojunction formation in MIECs for SIMFC applications. The research validates that intentional disordering at the interfaces and creating heterojunctions between different MIEC layers can pointedly improve ionic transport [ 201 , 202 ]. Integrating DFT simulations, the authors clarify the mechanisms behind the enhanced proton conduction in the MIECs ( Fig. 9 b). The simulations reveal the role of interface engineering in promoting efficient charge separation and averting internal electronic short circuits. This approach propositions a promising pathway for tailoring MIECs into high-performance SIMs, with improved ionic conduction at lower temperatures. It highlights the probability of DFT simulations in guiding the design and optimization of MIECs for SIMFCs. By understanding the interfacial disorder and heterojunction formation, researchers can tweak MIEC materials to achieve fast proton conduction, enabling the practical implementation of SIMFCs at lower operating temperatures.

6.1.3. Super proton conduction

In addition, DFT simulations have shed light on the unique surface super proton conduction mechanism observed in certain materials, including metal-insulating transition compounds like SmNiO 3 , when applied as MIECs in SIMFCs [ 200 , 205 ]. Yousaf et al. [ 200 ] not only explores the influence of interfacial disorder and heterojunction formation in MIECs but also digs into the surface super proton conduction mechanism observed in SmNiO 3 and LaNiO 3 when used as SIMFC materials. Lan et al. [ 206 ] use DFT to create a computational model of SmNiO 3 , a rare-earth perovskite. They explore how protons and oxygen atoms migrate within the material by calculating energy barriers and pathways through the crystal lattice. DFT permits the determination of electronic structure, energy levels, and band structure, crucial for understanding the interactions between protons, oxygen atoms, and the lattice. The researchers classify favorable migration pathways by analyzing potential energy surfaces, considering factors like lattice distortions and charge distributions. This approach offers atomic-level insights into the material's properties, which is valuable for optimizing its use in energy-related applications like PCFC/SIMFC. The unique proton conduction mechanism detected at the material's surface adds to the overall ionic conductivity, offering a promising pathway for developing high-performance SIMs. The surface super proton conduction mechanism joint with interfacial disorder and heterojunction formation opens up new boulevards for designing advanced SIMs with exceptional ionic conduction properties. These findings provide a comprehensive understanding of the underlying scientific principles governing the performance of MIECs in SIMFCs [ 201 ]. Proficiency and performance of SIMFCs depend on factors such as the electronic structure of the mixed ionic-electronic conductor, the catalytic activity of the electrodes, and the efficiency of ion diffusion through the electrolyte. Theoretical methods like DFT provide valuable insights into these aspects, aiding in designing and optimizing fuel cell materials and components. Including DFT simulations and the insights from the literature offer exciting prospects for future research in MIECs for SIMFCs. Further investigations into the surface and interfacial super proton conduction mechanism and its interplay with interface engineering will be crucial in unlocking the full potential of SIMFCs.
In addition to SmNiO 3 and LaNiO 3 , exploring other metal-insulating transition and heterostructure materials holds promise for achieving even higher ionic conductivity at lower temperatures. By leveraging DFT simulations and experimental studies, researchers can identify novel materials and optimize their structures for improved SIMFC performance [ 207 ]. Researchers can discover novel MIEC materials, optimized heterojunction configurations, and advanced interface engineering techniques by combining experimental studies and computational simulations. These advancements are key for developing fuel cell technology and realizing highly efficient and cost-effective SIMFCs for a sustainable energy future. Integrating DFT simulations, studying interfacial disorder, heterojunction formation, and investigating surface super proton conduction mechanisms provides an all-inclusive foundation for advancing MIECs to SIMs. The future directions delineated in this section pave the way for innovative research and development (R&D) in this rapidly developing field, ultimately contributing to realizing efficient and sustainable energy conversion technologies.

7. Future Directions and Outlook

In this final chapter, we discuss the future directions and potential advancements in evolving MIECs for advanced SIMs and SIMFCs. We explore emergent trends, research opportunities, and a key scientific understanding of the fundamentals that can outline the future of SIMFC advances and their applications.

7.1. Overview of SIMFC performance metrics

To assess the high performance of SIMFCs, it is essential to establish comprehensive metrics that can effectively evaluate their functionality and efficiency. This section discusses the key performance parameters used to assess SIMFCs and compare their designs and materials. One crucial metric is the ionic conductivity of SIMs, which is associated with significant electronic conduction. However, determining the specific contribution of each ion, such as H + and O 2− , poses a challenge. Traditional Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) methods, commonly used for measuring electrolyte conductivities in SOFCs and PCFCs based on sole O 2− or H + conducting properties can only provide the total conductivity in the SIM cases because both ions and electrons are mobile [ 156 , 208 ]. To address this issue [ 155 ] we have developed a new methodology and combined EIS measurements to obtain total conductivities and employ I-V characteristics analysis to determine the ionic conductivities for H + /O 2− [ 156 ]. In the I-V method, one may calculate the SIM (electrolyte function) ionic conductivity by extracting the linear ohmic conduction part, which corresponds to the current output due to ionic contribution ( Fig. 10 a and b). Thus, the calculation can convert the ohmic resistance to ionic conductivity of the SIM. However, it may contain some electrode resistance, which is negligible due to the electrode's tendency to have much higher conductivity than the electrolytes. Additionally, electronic conductivity is determined through direct current polarization methods compared to EIS (total charge contribution) combined fuel cell I-V (ionic contribution). To further identify the contribution of H + , a standard proton conductor filter method is applied in SIMFCs, commonly using one or two proton-filtering sides, where the BZY/BZCY is often used as reported extensively in the literature. Because the BZY/BZCY is a well-known proton conductor, which only allows H + to pass through the SIM, thus we measure the device I-V curves to compare that without using the BZY/BZCY; we can determine H + contribution and hence conductivity in the SIMs. It is a common, widespread case reported in the literature that the SIMFC with the BZY/BZCY proton filters can display a 10–20 ​% less power output than without the filtering layer(s). Thus, one can determine a proton-dominant property in SIMs and SIMFCs [ 209 ].
In addition to ionic conductivity measurement, current and power output are crucial metrics for assessing SIMFC performance. These metrics allow us to evaluate the level of ionic conductivity in SIMs and the effectiveness of device fabrication technologies. EIS measurements are often accompanied to determine the polarization resistances caused by the electrodes and interfaces between the electrodes and SIM membrane ( Fig. 10 c). The curves display the ohmic resistance (R o ) at high frequencies, a small semicircle indicating charge transfer at intermediate frequencies, and a more significant arc representing mass transfer at low frequencies. The samples demonstrate decreased ohmic resistances and enhanced electrode reactions at higher temperatures. The data is fitted using an equivalent circuit, and each process's characteristic capacitance (Ci) can be calculated accordingly.
In SIMFCs, the total electrical conductivity (σt) can be determined from the simulated ohmic resistance, encompassing ionic and electronic resistances. A novel method combining electrochemical impedance spectroscopy and direct-current polarization is also used to differentiate the electronic and ionic conductivities of SIMs. Based on Huggins's method, the EIS method employs two semicircles in the Nyquist plot to represent the parallel combination of electronic resistance and geometrical capacitance at low frequencies and ionic resistance and geometrical capacitance at high frequencies. The absence of a low-frequency tail indicates the shunting of interfacial capacitance by the electronic current. A typical Nyquist plot and the equivalent circuit shown in the inset which is used to fit the electronic and ionic resistances ( Fig. 10 d). A constant DC polarization is applied to the pellet with ion-blocking electrodes, and the pellet electronic resistance can be calculated. By considering these performance metrics, we can gain valuable insights into the conductivity levels of SIMs, the impact of device fabrication techniques, and the overall performance of SIMFCs [ [210] , [211] , [212] ].
Furthermore, in order to ensure the effectiveness and reliability of SIMFCs, it is important to assess their performance parameters. It is crucial to recognize problems like short circuits, which may significantly hinder the fuel cell's overall performance, in order to appropriately evaluate these factors. Various sophisticated techniques can be utilized to detect short circuits in MIECs and SIMs. A useful method for measuring the fuel cell's impedance over a range of frequencies is Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS). The internal resistance of the cell and other electrochemical characteristics can be examined with EIS by examining the impedance spectrum. By finding inconsistencies in the impedance data that correlate with disruptions in the cell's regular functioning, this study assists in the detection of short circuits.
Equivalent Circuit Modeling (ECM) is an additional useful technique. To accomplish this, an accurate equivalent circuit model of the fuel cell must be designed in order to imitate its electrical activity. ECM can assist in understanding how short circuits affect the fuel cell's performance by comparing the simulated findings with the actual readings. This technique enables a deeper awareness of the precise parts impacted by the short circuit and how it affects the cell's overall electrochemical operations.
Monitoring voltage is another simple yet efficient method. Since short circuits frequently result in an abrupt reduction in voltage, constant cell voltage monitoring may assist in the detection of these problems. Any unusual voltage fluctuations can be promptly detected by putting up a real-time monitoring system, indicating the need for more investigation into the reliability of the cell. Combining these techniques offers an extensive method to detect fuel cell short circuits [ [213] , [214] , [215] ].
These metrics provide a quantitative basis for evaluating SIMs and devices and comparing designs and materials. They play an important role in optimizing and advancing SIMFC technology, allowing us to make informed decisions in developing more advanced materials and technologies.

7.2. Unique electron-ion (e-i) coupling in SIMs and SIMFCs

As detailed in the preceding Section “Junction Fuel Cell Devices” our focus converges on diverse junctions within SIMFCs, employing SIMs as the foundational material. In SIMFCs, a distinctive characteristic known as BIEF sets them apart from conventional SOFCs and PCFCs, which rely on ionic electrolytes. This differentiation engenders a complex interplay encompassing electron-hole distributions, defect concentrations, and the BIEF itself, culminating in an extraordinary phenomenon termed EIC (electron-ion coupling). Within the confines of this interplay, a unique landscape of charge transport mechanisms unfolds within the field of SIM and SIMFC. Crucially, this intricate interplay orchestrates field-constrained electronic mobility, effectively preventing the undesirable passage of electrons through internal devices and averting short-circuiting predicaments. Simultaneously, this intricate synergy propels ionic transport towards enhancing ionic conductivity, over the performance of conventional electrolyte materials.
Many vital electrocatalytic reactions, such as HOR and ORR, depend on EIC. This mechanism involves the transfer of ions and electrons, which can result in the formation of a thermodynamically stable or coordinated intermediate through initial electron transfer (ET) or ion transfer (IT). Alternatively, the process may proceed consecutively without forming an intermediate. Electrocatalysts at the electrode interface often facilitate these reactions, which typically require multiple electron and ion transfers. The transfers are frequently coupled with other chemical reactions, illustrating the intricacy of EIC in electrocatalysis [ 216 , 217 ]. EIC is a fundamental operation of SIMFCs by enabling electrochemical reactions at the electrodes and promoting efficient energy conversion. An overview of the general operation of e-i coupling in SIMFCs is given below: A fuel source, such as hydrogen, is provided to the anode of a SIMFC. The fuel molecule gives the anode a proton (H + ) and an electron (e − ). The proton then travels through the SIM and is transported to the anode/membrane interface. Usually, air is supplied to the cathode, where oxygen gas fusions with incoming electrons (that come in through the external circuit) to create ions, which subsequently permeate through the membrane and enter the anodic layer. The total ionic conductivity of the membrane is influenced by the ion (O 2− ) migration from the cathode into the membrane. Ion transport via the fuel cell membrane is facilitated by the presence of EIC since the membrane is composed of semiconducting materials. The movement of charge carriers and the acceleration of electrochemical reactions are made possible by this mechanism, which permits the transfer of ions and electrons. Because it enables the transformation of chemical energy contained in fuels into electrical energy. Multiple mechanisms could be involved in this process in SIMFCs, with the redox mechanism being one of the more important ones. According to Wu et al., this process involves ion transport coupled with the redox cation couple of M n and M n-1 . It is based on a redox reaction combining metal cations and ions that support EIC transport, such as the Fe + -Fe 2+ transition metal cations [ 218 , 219 ]. The simultaneous movement of ions and electrons in these processes keeps the charges neutral ( Fig. 11 ).
Furthermore, a significant part in EIC could be performed by the Schottky junction (SJ). Particularly with p-type semiconductors, a Schottky barrier can develop at the interface between the anodic metal and the semiconductor membrane in an SJ-SIMFC device. This barrier generates a built-in electric field (BIEF) that directs energy from the metal side toward the semiconductor by generating a depletion layer at the interface [ 220 ]. This BIEF lowers electrode polarization loss by preventing electron crossover from the anode to the membrane and promoting the passage of ions (O 2− ) from the cathode to the membrane. The efficiency of SIMFCs depends on electron charge separation, charge transfer, ions transfer, and assistance with EIC transfer, all of which are highlighted by this procedure.
Overall, the EIC mechanism intrinsic to SIM/SIMFC involves the simultaneous movement of electrons and ions through different pathways and regions. That is, the localized electrons movement, in parallel to long-range translational paths governing ion transport. This allows for efficient ion transport, charge transfer and the promotion of electrochemical reactions, leading to enhanced fuel cell performance [ 49 , 164 ]. So, the SIMFC as a device collectively drive the enhanced ion transport, and electrochemical reactions underlying electricity production ( Fig. 11 ), where the nano-redox and ion redox couplings commonly exist for realizing the EIC functions and SIMFC performances. As we navigate towards a comprehensive understanding of this intricate landscape, the fields of semiconductor ionics and semiconductor electrochemistry emerge as burgeoning domains, poised to reshape the reader's comprehension and drive.
As discussed above, there is always a concern about how to solve the electronic short-circuiting issue in the case of SIMFCs. Therefore, various junction devices have been widely reported in the literature using different SIM and SIMFC technologies [ 124 , 199 ]. However, a basic question is, why do we always bring up this electronic issue with the SIMFC, and why we could not do a conventional way to get rid of it simply by using ionic electrolytes, e.g., YSZ, doped ceria, and proton conducting perovskite based on BaZrO 3 and BaCeO 3 oxide electrolytes? In fact, all these electrolyte materials with sufficient ionic conductivities at higher temperatures do not show high performance in SOFC/PCFC metrics at lower temperatures, e.g., <600 ​°C because lower operating temperatures are the demand and way forward to technology development for commercial applications. Therefore, new materials must be designed and developed to realize low temperatures as SIMFC aims at 300–550 ​°C. The next question is, why do we need to use SIMs? Let us further analyze: i) available ionic ceramic electrolytes do not meet the requirement of working below 600 ​°C with sufficient conductivities and device performance; ii) FCs based on SIMs have demonstrated numerous advantages as mentioned above from comprehensive literature reports; iii) the electronic short circuit issue solved through junction formation, even simplified as a single layer device technology; iv) SIMs always exhibit sufficient high ionic conductivity, about 0.1 ​S/cm level at 550 ​°C, the electrolyte material challenge is at some level solved in this way; v) Now is the time to address this critical scientific understanding where the EIC is emphasized. This is an ongoing research direction and hot topic based on hundreds of SIMFC demonstrations reported in the literature. Therefore, semiconductor ionics and semiconductor electrochemistry are the emerging fields that are establishing and progressing [ 221 ]. The EIC is another scientific topic beyond this mini-review, but it should be addressed for attention in future trends and direction in SIMFC continuous R&D.

7.3. SIMFC materials with optimized EIC transfer/transport properties

As highlighted in the previous section, developing new materials with optimized electron-ion coupling (e-i) transfer and transport properties is crucial in advancing SIMFCs. In this section, we delve into recent advancements in material design, composition, and Nanostructuring techniques that aim to enhance e-i coupling within SIMs, thereby improving the overall performance of SIMFCs. Researchers have explored various strategies for material design to enhance e-i coupling in SIMFCs. Recent developments in semiconductor ionics/electrochemistry have [ 131 ] introduced different materials designs and development for superionic conductors by selecting elements and their compositions carefully to create such materials that hold supporting electronic and ionic conduction properties. By tuning the energy band structure and optimizing the ionic migration pathways via surface and interfacial engineering, the materials can be tailored to exhibit e-i coupling behavior, facilitating efficient charge transfer and transport through SIMs during SIMFC operation.
One of the commonly used methods for material design and development is “doping”. Incorporating doping elements into the material lattice is a potent technique for tailoring the electron and ion-conducting properties in SIMs. A fundamental principle from semiconductor ionics underscores this approach: a) for the oxides with dominant ion-conduction, electronic elements are employed, particularly transition metal cations, preferably to increase the electronic conduction; meanwhile, b) for dominant electronically conducting oxides, ionic elements are employed such as Ce, Sm, Gd, etc., as the dopants are recommended. Strategically, doping the host material with specific elements, concentration and mobility of charge carriers can be adjusted, whereas, a harmonious balance between electronic and ionic conductivities is achieved. This, in turn, enhances the coupling characteristics between electrons and ions. Doping strategies can be applied in the case of both bulk and surface materials. Introducing elements with distinct valence states or adjusting doping concentrations, optimizes the charge transport properties in SIMs. Surface and interface engineering stands as a powerful methodology for fine-tuning the functionality of SIM materials, especially in the context of hybrid or hetero-structures. The role of surface and interface is pivotal in dictating the electron and ion transport across the SIMs. Semiconductor ionics provide essential designing strategies and critical parameters for surface and interface engineering, respectively.
Through meticulous surface and interface engineering techniques, our objective is to optimize the architectural structures of materials for charge kinetics, ensuring optimal surficial and interfacial properties among diverse particles, layers, or components within the SIM. This encompasses tailoring specific surficial and interfacial structures, introducing interfacial coatings, or controlling interfacial defects and grain boundaries. The scope of surfaces and interfaces spans various material attributes, encompassing semiconducting (p-type or n-type) behavior, insulating, metallic state, ionic conduction etc. Manipulation of surfaces and interfaces facilitates the modulation and equilibrium of electronic and ionic fractions as well as their mobility. This, in turn, augments the efficiency of electron-ion coupling and thereby bolsters the performance of SIMFCs. Furthermore, it is imperative to underscore the intricate interplay between surface and interface parameters in the designing of photocatalysts. This holistic approach ensures a comprehensive grasp of the nuanced relationship between surface and interface characteristics yielding insights critically for achieving the enhanced SIMFC performance and broader range of energy applications.
In addition, the nanostructure approach is always useful. Nanostructures offer promising avenues in order to enhance e-i coupling in SIMFC materials. Researchers can modify the material's electronic and ionic transport properties by controlling the size, shape, and distribution of any-scale features, such as nanoparticles, nanowires, or nanoscale thin films. A typical example is ceria, whose electronic and ionic conductivities vary significantly with particle size, where at some particular particle scales, the electronic and ionic conductivities can match with each other. The nanostructure approach provides material designs with a high surface-to-volume ratio, facilitating efficient charge transfer and diffusion processes. Additionally, nanostructures can exhibit enhanced catalytic activity, promoting electrode reactions and improving overall device performance. Through the strategies of material design i.e., doping, interface engineering, and nanostructure approaches, researchers can optimize the e-i coupling for improved transfer and transport properties of SIM materials. The ultimate goal is to minimize the polarization losses during charge transfer and to decrease the charge transport resistance, which improves charge carrier mobility and enhances the overall device performance. By advancing the understanding of e-i coupling mechanisms and exploring innovative material synthesis techniques, high-performance SIMFCs can be developed with improved power, efficiency, stability, and scalability.

7.4. Challenges and limitations of using e-i coupling

While EIC holds great potential for enhancing SIMFC performance, several challenges and limitations need to be addressed. Some critical challenges are associated with harnessing e-i coupling in SIMFCs, highlighting the areas that require further research and development (R&D) efforts.

7.4.1. Material stability

SIMFC materials must maintain structural integrity and chemical stability under operating conditions. The high temperatures and corrosive environments within fuel cells can challenge the stability of SIMs and their EIC properties. Material degradation, phase transformations, and the formation of unwanted secondary phases can adversely affect the SIMFC performance with time. Developing stable materials and understanding the degradation mechanisms are crucial for long-term and reliable SIMFC operation.

7.4.2. Degradation mechanisms

SIMFCs are subjected to various degradation mechanisms that can impair their performance over time. These degradation processes can include changes in chemical reactions, deformation of SIM and electrode microstructure and morphology during the fuel cell operations, SIM decomposition, phase separation, heterostructural changes, and material interdiffusion. Identifying and mitigating these degradation pathways is essential for maintaining the electron and ion-conducting properties and e-i coupling efficiency and prolonging the lifespan of SIMFCs.

7.4.3. Electrode reactions

Efficient electrode reactions are extremely important for overall SIMFC performance. Achieving simultaneous electron and ion transfer at the electrodes, SIM interfaces are essential in facilitating the electrochemical reactions involved in the fuel cell operation. However, sluggish electrode kinetics, limited electrochemical active area, and catalyst degradation can impede the electrode reactions and hinder the EIC efficiency. Developing high-performance catalysts and optimizing electrode structures, is a key research area to improve SIMFC performance at low temperatures, typically 300–500 ​°C.

7.4.4. Interfacial phenomena

Interfaces among different phases in SIMs (e.g., semiconductor and ionic two-phase heterostructure), and the components in SIMFCs (i.e., the electrodes/SIM interfaces), play a critical role in facilitating EIC, charge transfer and transport processes in the SIM and SIMFC. However, interfacial phenomena, including interfacial resistance, charge transfer limitations, interfacial ion conducting paths, and interface stability, can impact the overall performance of SIMFCs. Understanding and controlling these interfacial factors, are essential for optimizing EIC and improving SIMFC efficiency. Addressing these challenges and limitations associated with EIC in SIMFCs requires interdisciplinary research in materials science, electrochemistry, and engineering, and therefore, the field of semiconductor ionics is emerging. Collaboration among scientists, engineers, and industry stakeholders is crucial to overcome these hurdles and advance SIMFC technology. By addressing these challenges, we can pave the way for the widespread implementation of SIMFCs as efficient and sustainable energy conversion devices.

7.5. Utilizing Artificial Intelligence (AI) to promote developments in SIMFCs

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a major development that can improve the overall efficiency, sustainability, and reliability of SIMFCs. AI can be used to enhance SIMFC performance, improve the science of materials, detect problems more accurately, integrate systems into smart grids, and evaluate the environmental and economic effects of these developments. First, existing SIMFC data can be used to train machine learning models like as neural networks and regression algorithms to foresee and optimize performance metrics like efficiency and power output.
Moreover, by employing methods like reinforcement learning to determine the best control policies, AI might be integrated into control systems to dynamically modify operating parameters in real-time. AI is crucial for troubleshooting and identifying defects in SIMFCs, which ultimately prolongs their life. Outliers can be found using unsupervised learning methods like clustering, and various fault types can be classified over time using supervised learning models that can be built. With the use of time-series analysis, predictive maintenance algorithms, and deterioration pattern analysis, AI can also estimate how long fuel cells will last before needing maintenance [222].
AI can also use genetic algorithms and other optimization approaches to optimize SIMFC structure design. AI can make it easier for SIMFCs to be integrated into smart grids, resulting in more effective energy distribution and management. AI systems can manage several SIMFCs in a grid, optimizing energy storage and balancing load. Simpler heuristic-based models can be used in early implementations to show viability, and as more data becomes available, more complex models can be included. AI has the capability to oversee and assess the environmental effects of SIMFCs and guarantee adherence to rules. The environmental impact of SIMFC operations can be estimated and tracked using early models [223].
AI integration into SIMFCs requires a step-by-step process, starting with more basic models and gradually incorporating more advanced techniques. The ability to explain and interpretability are given top priority, so we can ensure that these AI models are reliable and efficient for operators and stakeholders. There will be major improvements in performance, dependability, and sustainability as a result of this gradual and transparent integration of AI in SIMFC technology.

8. Summary and perspectives

By utilizing SIM technology, the reviewed work aims to explore the latent of MIECs on existing information and give fresh perspectives on sustainable electrochemical energy conversion. MIECs, which possess both electronic and ionic conduction, offer unique opportunities for improving the performance and efficiency of SIMFCs. Compared to typical SOFCs, SIMFCs have several advantages, including higher ionic conductivity, which improves performance by enabling higher current and power outputs at low temperatures, a simple construction (three in one), etc. Yet, it is advised that the following opposing views be considered for upcoming study and development: Building an optimal concept of MIECs and their structural properties. Furthermore, different types of MIECs, including perovskites, fluorites, layer-structured oxides, and spinals, were explored regarding their potential applications in SIMFCs.
More research and advanced efforts are needed to focus on current challenges in this field, including durability, cost-effectiveness, and scalability. These challenges and limitations can be overcome via progress in designing new materials, advanced synthesis techniques, and in-situ characterization. Finally, the engineering of the device will be instrumental in realizing the full potential of SIMFCs. It shifted our focus towards developing MIECs specifically tailored for SIMs. Besides, the article emphasized the importance of e-i coupling, as it is a unique characteristic of SIMs being different from the MIEC, revealing a promising avenue for further advancements in the material functionality and efficiency of SIMFCs. By leveraging this concept of e-i coupling, researchers can explore novel approaches to improve the development of highly advanced electron-ion conductors for fuel cells. Furthermore, the obligation for materials with optimal e-i coupling capabilities has been addressed, highlighting the relevance of triple charge transport perovskites as SIMs. Scientists are mindful of the difficulties in using e-i coupling SIMFCs, including degradation and material stability. Overcoming these challenges will be crucial for successfully implementing and commercializing SIMFC technology. To propel improvements in sustainable energy systems, research collaboration, the optimization of e-i coupling processes, and the discovery of novel materials are critical to the future of SIMFCs.
MIECs play a particularly important role in SIMFCs. These fuel cells are based on semiconductor ionic membranes, composed of semiconductor characteristics and the ability to conduct ions. Several developments could stem from the incorporation of MIECs in SIMFCs.
  • 1.
    The primary objective of research is to find and develop new MIEC materials that have improved structural stability, increased ionic and electronic conductivities, and improved catalytic capabilities. To attain the required characteristics, this entails experimenting with various formulations, dopants, and manufacturing techniques.
  • 2.
    To address the present issues in the field, such as scalability, cost-effectiveness, and durability, a deeper investigation needs to be done. Advances in in-situ characterization, powerful synthesis methods, and innovative material design can help overcome these obstacles and constraints. subsequently, attaining the highest potential of SIMFCs will depend significantly on the device's engineering.
  • 3.
    Significant progress has been made in establishing long-term SIMFC durability through the development of compatible electrode materials. Additionally, the most crucial step in enhancing the longevity and performance of SIMFC is the development of SIM electrodes with improved redox stability and increased catalytic activity. To improve electrode kinetics and reduce polarization losses, various materials such as MIEC, perovskite, and composite materials with a fluorite structure should be investigated.
  • 4.
    A key factor in the overall effectiveness of SIMFCs is the interface between the electrodes and the MIEC membrane. To improve charge transfer and increase ionic conductivity, these interfaces are being engineered using sophisticated approaches.
  • 5.
    Although SIM is a triple-conducting material that can serve as both electrodes and electrolytes, implementing SIM in fuel cells is highly simple and accessible. Utilizing SIM also increases the device's durability and enables low-temperature operation. Additionally, as an electrode, the newly designed functional semiconductor TCO membrane reduces interfacial polarization losses, which are significant problems in conventional SOFCs. Furthermore, TCO can attain excellent fuel cell efficiency, with an estimated power output of 1000 ​mW ​cm −2 at less than 500 ​°C. The standard SOFC challenges of cost and fabrication can be alleviated by the SMFC's simple design and inexpensive materials. Additionally, the redox reaction in SIM, a synergistic effect between the electrons and ions built in the multi-ion electric field, improves the transportation of the ions.
  • 6.
    Sustainable and affordable materials and fabrication techniques are necessary for SIMFCs to be economically feasible. Our objective is to create manufacturing procedures that can create enormous amounts of high-quality MIEC membranes without diminishing their ability to function.
  • 7.
    In order to enable sustainable and effective energy conversion efficiency, SIMFC can be linked with renewable energy sources, such as biomass, biogas, and hydrogen created from renewable energy sources. Moreover, this kind of interaction might promote the shift toward cleaner energy sources in the future.
  • 8.
    The commercial viability of SIMFCs depends heavily on their long-term endurance. To better understand how MIECs deteriorate and create plans to extend these materials' useful lives in real-world situations, research is being done.
The aforementioned perspective, difficulties, obstacles, and possible progress in the field of SIMFCs have the goal to enhance fuel cell efficiency, lower costs, broaden the range of applications, and possibly accelerate commercialization. There is a lot of potential for MIECs and SIMFCs to support environmental sustainability. With the help of these materials, numerous industrial processes especially those involving energy conversion and storage can dramatically lower their carbon footprint, creating cleaner, more effective energy systems. Through enhancing energy storage and conversion efficiency, MIECs and SIMFCs can augment the utilization of natural resources in a more sustainable manner by diminishing dependence on fossil fuels and encouraging the adoption of renewable energy sources. Creating plans for these materials' recycling and reuse can also reduce waste and support the circular economy's guiding principles. More sustainable manufacturing techniques, such as lower energy use, less waste, and the use of eco-friendly materials, can result from developments in the synthesis and processing of MIECs and SIMFCs. MIECs and SIMFCs can fully realize their promise to contribute to environmental sustainability by resolving these limitations and concentrating on these future research directions as depicted in Fig. 12 .
Looking ahead, appropriate theories and calculations should direct future investigation and development. Notably, the physical characteristics and effects of the integrated electric field are produced by various hetero-junctions, such as p-i-n junctions, bulk and planar p-n junctions, and Schottky junctions. These insights provided a comprehensive understanding of the experimental and engineering aspects of SIMFC technology.
In conclusion, this article sheds light on the potential benefits and challenges of developing MIECs (expanding to TCOs) for advanced SIMFCs, and represents a promising direction for advancing the capabilities of SIMs in fuel cell applications. The insights provided pave the way into future research into SIMs, highlighting their unique properties and potential benefits for SIMFC technology. This review emphasizes the vital role of semiconductor ionics in leading material design for MIEC development, demonstrating its potential to transform the production of high-performance mixed conductors. By leveraging the knowledge gained from traditional perovskite oxides (MIEC), researchers can unlock new frontiers in fuel cell technology, leading to more efficient and sustainable energy conversion systems ( Fig. 12 ). Continued research efforts in this area will drive the development of MIECs/TCOs, leading to more efficient and sustainable energy conversion technologies.

Cited by (0)

Bushra Bibi is currently pursuing her PhD degree at the School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University, and completed her Master of science degree from COMSATS University Islamabad, Lahore Campus. Her research primarily focuses on development of semiconductor ionics and semiconductor electrochemistry for next generation energy device applications.
Atif Nazar is currently pursuing his PhD degree at the School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University, and completed his Master of science degree from COMSATS University Islamabad, Lahore Campus. His research primarily focuses on creating and developing semiconductor ionics and semiconductor electrochemistry for next generation energy device applications.
Professor Bin Zhu , Professor at Southeast University and Xi'an Jiaotong University, is also a Visiting Professor at Loughborough University, UK, and a former senior researcher at the Royal Swedish University of Technology. He is a recipient of the Hubei 100 Talents Plan and Jiangsu Innovative Talents program. Specializing in semiconductor ionics and semiconductor electrochemistry for energy devices, he has published over 400 papers in refereed journals, with about 17,000 citations, H-index 68. Listed in Stanford University's “Top 2% Scientists in the World” for lifetime and annual impact, he has been recognized as China's Highly Cited Scholar for a decade, and is currently a co-editor for several international journals, including Energy Materials and the Journal of Energy Science and Engineering.
Professor Jung-Sik Kim : Dr Kim is a Professor in Energy Technology at Beihang University, and he is an internationally well-experienced leading engineer with a research record in electrochemical energy materials and their applicable systems. He held multiple professor positions in various UK institutes, including Loughborough University and Imperial College London prior to joining Beihang University. Prof Kim's research interests go into characterising the level of strain kinetics and related stresses to address the means of matter transfer, and a keen developer to apply such concepts towards designing new energy devices. He invented in-situ stress measuring techniques for the powder sintering processes, and a hydrogen composition analyser based on the understanding of oxygen ion transport phenomena. He constantly supports knowledge transfer to related industries to advance their products.
Professor Sining Yun: Obtained his PhD degree from Xi'an Jiaotong University in 2007 and was a postdoctoral fellow in Yonsei University (Korea) in 2008–2009. He was a visiting professor at the State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals (China) in 2012, University of Reading (UK) in 2016, and Prof. Michael Graetzel and Prof. Anders Hagfeldt's laboratory at EPFL (Switzerland) in 2017. He is currently a Research Director and Group Leader of Functional Materials Laboratory. He is an author/corresponding author of more than 220 SCI-papers in internationally reputed peer review (ISI) journals with H-index of 57, a reviewer and arbitral referee of more than 140 SCI-journals, an editor of 9 books and book chapters, an international editorial board member (International Journal of Green Energy, Oxford Open Energy, etc.), Chair/Co-chair of several international conferences, and an associate editor of Energy Materials journal with impact factor of 11.8, OAE Publishing. His current research interests lie in new energy materials and their applications in solar cells, fuel cells, supercapacitors, hydrogen generation and anaerobic digestion, etc.

Bushra Bibi, Atif Nazar and Bin Zhu contributed equally to this work.

Strictly Necessary Cookies

Always active

These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.
